facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 710 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 710 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 1, 1967 of Mysore High Court in Sales Tax Appeal No. 8 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 1, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Sales Tax Appeal No. 8 of 1966.

facts.text: Commercial Tax Officer passed assessment order dated March 28, 1964 for assessment year 1958-59 including turnover of coaches models 407, 408, 411.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer, by assessment order dated March 28, 1964, in respect of the assessment year 1958-59, included the turnover in respect of the supply of these coaches.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer rejected assessee's contention that no sale involved in works contract citing McKenzie v. State of Bombay and Jiwan Singh v. State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer rejected the contention of the assessee that there was no sale involved in the execution of the works-contract in view of certain decisions of the High Courts e.g., McKenzie

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes confirmed the assessment order in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes confirmed the order.

facts.text: Commissioner of Commercial Taxes confirmed the order in revision, observing contracts for manufacture and supply, under-frames remain property of Railway Board.

anchor.surface_text: In revision the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes also came to the same conclusion. He observed The contracts specifically mentioned that the under-frame shall always remain the property of the Railway Board.

facts.text: Railway Board supplied underframes free of cost to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the order placed with the assessee company here was for the manufacture and supply of railway coaches. ... the underframes were transferred to the assessee company free of cost

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed assessee's appeal under s.24 of Mysore Sales Tax Act read with s.9 of Central Sales Tax Act and set aside inclusion of turnover for coaches models 407, 408, 411.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then took an appeal to the High Court of Mysore under s. 24(1) of the Mysore Sales Tax Act read with s. 9(3) of the Central Sales-tax Act. The High Court ... allowed the appeal and set aside the order including the turnover relating to the construction of railway coaches, models 407, 408 and 411.

facts.text: Ministry of Railways wrote to Hindustan Aircraft Ltd. on February 3, 1955 regarding coaching programme 1955-56 for 180 coaches: Third Class Coaches B.G. model 407 and Military Coaches M type model 408.

anchor.surface_text: On February 3, 1955, the Ministry of Railways wrote to the Hindustan Aircraft Ltd. regarding the coaching programme 1955-56. ... Third Class Coaches B.G. model 407 Military Coaches M type model 408 Total 180

facts.text: Railway Board placed order dated May 4, 1957 with assessee for manufacture and supply of 180 Broad Gauge Class III Coaches model 407 at provisional price Rs. 94,731 per coach without wheels, axles and under-frames.

anchor.surface_text: Railway Board No. 57/147/RE 163 dated May 4, 1957. ... for the manufacture and supply of the following coaching stock ... 180 Broad Gauge 55-B-14 Class III Coaches fully furnished to model 407 ... Price per coach ... Rs. 94,731/- ... without wheels and axles and under-frames

facts.text: Wheelsets and Underframes for the stock supplied free of cost f.o.r. assessee's work siding.

anchor.surface_text: Wheelsets and Underframes The Wheelsets and Underframes for the stock will be supplied to you free of cost f.o.r. your work siding.

facts.text: Advance payment of 90% of value of materials made to assessee on receipt of materials and production of certificate from Inspecting Authority.

anchor.surface_text: Terms of payment Advance on account payment to the extent of 90% of the value of the materials shall be made to you on receipt of materials and on production of a certificate from the Inspecting Authority.

facts.text: Indemnity bond by Hindustan Aircraft Ltd. holding stores and articles in respect of advances as property in trust for President of Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: Hindustan Aircraft Ltd., hereby undertake to hold at their works at Bangalore for and on behalf of the President of the Union of India, and as his property in trust for him the Stores and articles in respect of which advances are made to them

facts.text: Assessee sent invoice No. 31009 dated 15-10-1956 for materials worth Rs. 2,60,374-12-0 for model 407 coaches, received 90% advance Rs. 2,34,517-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: Invoice No. 31009 of 15-10-1956 ... materials for the value of Rs. 2,60,374-12-0 were purchased by the company for 407 model coaches. ... asking payment of Rs. 2,34,517-4-0 being 90 per cent

facts.text: Supreme Court held it is a pure works contract, no sale of coaches, as materials used belong to Railways.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts it seems to us that it is a pure works contract. We are unable to agree that when all the material used in the construction of a coach belongs to the Railways there can be any sale of the coach itself.

facts.text: Commercial Tax Officer reported that assessee drew advances from Railway Board for materials utilised in completing contracts.

anchor.surface_text: My findings revealed that as and when they purchased materials, they sent to the Railway Board an invoice ... 90 per cent of the value of these materials was then paid

facts.text: No materials for which advance not drawn were utilised for building coaches.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that no materials, for which advance was not drawn, was utilised for building the coaches.

facts.text: Constructions done at particular shed separately located, materials kept separately.

anchor.surface_text: The constructions are said to be done at particular shed which is separately located. ... All the materials procured for constructions of coaches are said to be kept separately in this section alone.

facts.text: Inspection of stock by representative C.M.E. Southern Railway before despatch.

anchor.surface_text: Inspection Authority The inspection of this stock shall be carried out by a representative C.M.E. Southern Railway before the coaches are despatched.

facts.text: For model 411, wheelsets and underframes not supplied free of cost unlike 407 and 408.

anchor.surface_text: The only difference as far as coach model No. 411 is concerned is that in that case the wheelsets and underframes are not supplied free of cost but otherwise there is no essential difference in the terms.

issues.text: the only question involved is whether the delivery by the respondent-Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd. to the Railway Board of railway coaches model 407, 408 and 411 is liable to sales tax under the Central Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Mysore the only question involved is whether the deliveryby the respondent-Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd.-hereinafter referred to as the assessee-to the Railway Board of railway coaches model 407, 408 and 411 is liable to sales tax under the Central Sales Tax

arguments.claim: No inspection during execution as normal in works contract, only after completion

anchor.surface_text: The agreement does not also contemplate any inspection in the course of execution as would normally be provided for in a works contract. The only inspection is after completion

arguments.claim: Advances are only for security, materials hypothecated, part payment of price

anchor.surface_text: The condition that the materials become property of the Railway Board as and when purchased is only for purposes of providing adequate security for the advances. In the circumstances, the materials can be deemed to be hypothecated

holdings.text: it is a pure works contract. We are unable to agree that when all the material used in the construction of a coach belongs to the Railways there can be any sale of the coach itself.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts it seems to us that it is a pure works contract. We are unable to agree that when all the material used in the construction of a coach belongs to the Railways there can be any sale of the coach itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All materials used in construction vested in or supplied by Railways prior to incorporation, so no transfer of property in completed coaches constituting sale.

holdings.text: the answer to the question whether it is a works contract or it is a contract of sale depends upon the construction of the terms of the contract in the light of the surrounding circumstances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of contract determined by interpreting its terms considering salient features like ownership of materials, advances, and financial arrangements.

holdings.text: the property in the materials which are used for the construction of the coaches becomes the property of the President before it is used.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Indemnity bond explicitly provides that materials for which advances given are held as property in trust for President of India prior to use in construction.

holdings.text: The only difference as far as coach model No. 411 is concerned is that in that case the wheelsets and underframes are not supplied free of cost but otherwise there is no essential difference in the terms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of free supply for key components in model 411 does not alter essential terms or change character from works contract to sale.
